instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
Hey another <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board for repair.

The board came in with not booting up and saw corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> with Pin 12 without a track which I made a jumper to pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R8140</RESISTOR> and also replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>. Unfortunately it hasn't made any changes and I also didn't take a complete list of the voltages I was getting before attempting the repair so I've only got the measurements after the repairs.

The CPU is getting warm and I've check all the traces and rails but don't see anything else wrong with the board. Hopefully someone can advise what I could check on next.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
Post resistance to ground on all these rails:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
Check allso if you have short between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and any big coil from secondary supplies...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message: This does not sound good! PPBUS is low and CPU is getting warm. I suspect PPBUS is shorted to some secondary rail. Probably RIP.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 60Ohms
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> constantly going up towards infinity.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> around 0.483 KOhms 

Short can only be seen when put between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and L7130

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
L7130 is on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> line; check with other coils...
Any other big coil shows 50-60 ohms to ground?

Remove F7140 and see where the low value remains.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
okay somehow I find that L7520 is actually showing short with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> aswell.

ANd no some coils are showing 80 Ohms and some are showing way above that L7520 is showing around 2-5 Ohms.

I'll double check the situation with the fuse tomorrow.

Appreciate any help, thanks.

So <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> is shorted...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
As per schematic, pins 6/7/8 are tied together.
<TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> is shorted 1-6, that is the problem...

threads.message:
trying to check every component on the lines but removing the capacitors still showing the P5VS4 rail as short.

Any component in particular do you reckon i should check out?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
Checked if <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is shorting the rail, but that seems like its shorting it even with that chip removed.

Removing F7140 I can see that Pin 2 is showing the 60Ohms (low resistance value)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message: That seems like a short on pin 2 of PPBUS...inject voltage to see what heats up. Start low at 1 volt in case it's the CPU.

threads.message: I am getting 1.150V roughly on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> so should I start higher say 2V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
So you have 60 ohms at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Any secondary power rail (big coils) with same value?
If only L7520, then remove <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and check again.
Do NOT power up the board without <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>...

threads.message:
without <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> attached <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is still showing 60 Ohms

Every other coil is showing the same or similar resistances when put against <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

With <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> also removed it doesn't show any significant changes and no coils showing the same resistances as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (which is showing 35Ohms)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is still showing 60 Ohms"
---
"showing the same resistances as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (which is showing 35Ohms)"
Can you clarify the things please...
Also post resistance between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and L7520 too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
Okay my multimeter must've glitched on me, disregard that bit - "showing the same resistances as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (which is showing 35Ohms)"

The resistance values between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and L7520 is 60 Ohms

Taking a reading with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to ground is also showing 60 Ohms
When taking a resistance value from L7520 to ground it is showing 2 Ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
So you have the sort to ground on L7520.
Only 2 ohms will allow you find the culprit injecting voltage there.
Be aware, do not overtake 5.5V and keep ampers below power lab supply limit.
Start with 2V, that should mean 2W dispation and increase until get a hot element.
4-5W should be easy detected with the finger...

Remember, do NOT power up the board before resolder <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
should i remove L7520 before injecting the voltage or do it with the coil attached? 

Many thanks for everything!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message: No matters L7520, just remove the burnt <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
Shorted chips <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> removed both and the shorts where gone from everywhere and resistance values normalised.

Replaced the chips (including <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>) and short still gone. (blessed), made sure everything was still good and then plugged it in.

PPBUS was showing 12.6 Volts for awhile then dropped back to 1.150V.

L7520 and the whole rail isnt showing short anymore to ground or when checked between the coil and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 

But <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is showing short to ground and also showing short with L7560 (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message: Did you put back <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
Yeah I did I put a new <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>.

Many thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board gets warm, no fan spinning, not booting up, Corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>
threads.message:
I hope you didn't power up the board without <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> in any moment.
That is a good reason short <CHIP>U7560</CHIP>.

As you was able to eliminate the low values on 5V rail, you can do the same on 3.3V.
Be aware, this time PCH, or SMC could be burnt...
